argument.p: Typed Letter Signed ("J.D. Salinger"), 1 p, 8vo, New York, May 29, 1957, on New Yorker letterhead, to Garson Kanin, regarding adapting his stories for the stage; together with typed carbon of Kanin's May 16, 1957 letter to Salinger; housed together in custom clamshell box, with 1996 bookseller's receipt.

objectDesc.p: The document is a typed letter, signed by J.D. Salinger, dated May 29, 1957, and written on official New Yorker letterhead. It consists of one page, measuring 8vo (approximately 8 x 5 inches), a standard size for personal and business correspondence. The paper likely has a slightly aged appearance, possibly with minor discoloration or creases due to its age. The letter features typed text in a traditional typewriter font, with Salinger’s signature handwritten in ink at the bottom. Given its provenance and literary significance, the document is preserved in a custom clamshell box, ensuring protection and archival quality.

persName.note: J. D. Salinger (1919–2010) was an American writer best known for The Catcher in the Rye, a novel that became a defining work of 20th-century literature. His writing often explored themes of alienation, identity, and the struggles of adolescence. In addition to his famous novel, he wrote several short stories and novellas, including Nine Stories, Franny and Zooey, and Raise High the Roof Beam, Carpenters and Seymour: An Introduction. Despite his literary success, Salinger became increasingly reclusive, avoiding public attention and publishing little after the 1960s. His influence remains strong, with his works continuing to be widely read and analyzed.

persName.note: Garson Kanin (1912–1999) was an American writer, director, and playwright known for his contributions to theater, film, and literature. He wrote and directed several Broadway plays and collaborated with his wife, Ruth Gordon, on classic screenplays such as Adam’s Rib and Pat and Mike. Kanin also authored novels, memoirs, and non-fiction works, including Tracy and Hepburn, a biography of Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn. His sharp wit and storytelling talent made him a significant figure in mid-20th-century American entertainment.

place.note: New York City played a significant role in the lives of both J. D. Salinger and Garson Kanin. As a literary and cultural hub, the city influenced Salinger’s writing, with its energy and alienation reflected in The Catcher in the Rye. Kanin, deeply immersed in Broadway and Hollywood, thrived in its artistic circles, writing and directing for the stage and screen. Both men, though different in their careers—one a reclusive novelist, the other a vibrant playwright and filmmaker—left lasting marks on American literature and entertainment, with New York as a key backdrop to their creative journeys.

div.p: I'm afraid what you've heard is very true—I don't see any of my fictional characters in the theater—but I'm glad you liked ZOOEY, and glad you thought and bothered to write. My stand about the theater isn't a very happy one, considering that there are so many fine people putting on plays—I'm thinking especially of Elia Kazan whom I like very much—but I have an old and unshakable notion that I know what's best for my characters. Thank you, though. Sincerely,
